content.description: Vertical finger crack with no footholds on a shear vertical face.  A friend of mine, Scott Heckathorne (from the 80's) said he attempted this climb many times and wanted to get someone nationally ranked to try it as he was unable to make it past the crux at the top of the finger crack to where it flares open after a couple feet of being too small to get your fingers into.  Scott's theory was that if you could get past the flare that you could finish as there were some horizontal ridges for holds and a few above those.
content.location: Immediately to the right of the S-Crack.

content.description: Short route where crack on smooth rock is in a rough S shape.  Start by standing on the bottom foot or so of the crack and as it leans left you work your way up with a lean-back until it goes vertical an you move somewhat into the crack as it is wide enough for foot jams.
content.protection: Don't remember how we anchored this as it was 40 years ago.
content.location: Follow trail to the right of The Cave Route around the cliff, upward, into a shaded, open space.  To the left of a vertical cliff face of about 50 feet, is the "S Crack" but ends onto a sloping ledge.

content.description: Flat face, slightly overhanging with micro-holds.  Belay is from one of several small trees growing at the base.  It is a short climb but offers very little footholds.
content.protection: anchor to shrubs/trees set back from the top maybe 30 feet.
content.location: To the left of "The Cave Route" (facing the rock) about 20 feet, follow the same ledge to the left and up above a broken away slab to a slightly overhanging shear face.

content.description: A short climb, but fun.  Crux at start, fairly vertical.  After several feet dihedral opens up and becomes easier.  A layback all the way.
content.protection: Small trees at the top if memory serves.  Possibly some small boulders.
content.location: Further around to the left end of the cliff.  This is an upper section further to the left of LA Face as the ledge slants up.

climbs.name: Cinderella's Crack
climbs.fa: My brother completed it in 1982 or so.  I never did..

content.description: A roof about 5 feet out, flat.  A crack continues over the roof up into grass at the top.  Very short route, but the roof is just big enough to make it hard to keep your foot on the rock while reaching over the lip to the crack.  This is the crux.
content.location: Walk around to the right of the Cave Route and up the trail along the cliff to a shaded open area when you can scramble up to the top of the cliff.  Just to the left of this area is a roof about 5 feet out, flat.

climbs.name: The Cave
climbs.fa: I climbed it in 1979, others might have climbed it earlier.

content.description: An overhang near the top provides the crux.
content.protection: Tree anchor at the top for TR.
content.location: The tallest part of the cliff, with the overhang.  It's towards the center of the cliff.

content.description: Fall River is a sandstone escarpment, cut by the adjacent Fall River and with the aid of some blasting by the railroad.  It can be reached by walking eastward from the town of Fall River, Kansas 1.45 miles along the railroad tracks.  The area is generally shady, with trees along the top and base of the climb.  The sandstone is well indurated and not brittle.
